title: Understanding Ovarian Cysts
subtitle: What they are, how they're diagnosed, and what to expect

content.value:
Ovarian cysts are fluid-filled sacs that form in or on the ovaries. They are very common and usually form during ovulation.

Most are harmless, painless, and go away on their own. Many women get at least one cyst every month without knowing.

content.description: About 8% of premenopausal women develop larger cysts that need treatment.

content.title: See your doctor if you have:
content.description: These can be signs of a cyst or other underlying conditions.

items.text: Pelvic pain or unusual vaginal bleeding

content.value: There are several types of ovarian cysts, ranging from harmless to those requiring treatment.

items.title: Functional Cysts (Harmless)
items.content:
**Follicle Cysts:** Form when a follicle does not release an egg and keeps growing. Usually disappear within 1-3 months.

**Corpus Luteum Cysts:** Form when the follicle reseals after releasing an egg and fills with fluid. Usually resolve in a few weeks.

items.title: Other Benign Cysts
items.content:
**Endometriomas** — caused by endometriosis

**Dermoid cysts** — formed from cells present from birth

**Cystadenomas** — fluid-filled and can grow large

**PCOS cysts** — multiple tiny cysts from hormone imbalance

items.title: Malignant (Cancerous) Cysts
items.content: Rare, but more common after menopause. Must be assessed to rule out ovarian cancer.

content.title: Most cysts cause no symptoms
content.description: But larger or problematic cysts may cause discomfort.

items.title: Common Symptoms
items.description: Bloating, swelling or pressure in the lower abdomen; Pelvic pain (dull or sharp, may come and go); Pain during periods or sex; Pain with nausea/vomiting if the ovary twists; Sudden severe pain if a cyst ruptures

items.title: Less Common Symptoms
items.description: Lower back or thigh ache; Trouble fully emptying bladder or bowel; Breast tenderness; Unexplained weight gain; Needing to urinate more often; Unusual vaginal bleeding

content.value: Certain factors may increase your risk of developing ovarian cysts.
Most ovarian cysts do not affect your ability to get pregnant.

items.text: Most ovarian cysts do not affect fertility
Some conditions (like PCOS or endometriosis) can affect fertility
Large cysts during pregnancy may need monitoring or removal

content.title: Important Note
content.description: If you're trying to conceive and have concerns about ovarian cysts, speak to your doctor.

content.title: Diagnostic Process
content.description: Your doctor will use one or more methods to diagnose ovarian cysts.

steps: Pelvic exam to check for swelling or tenderness
Ultrasound scan to view the cyst's size and type
Blood tests to check hormones or rule out cancer
MRI if needed for more detailed images

content.title: Monitoring
content.description: Most cysts are monitored over time to see if they shrink on their own.

content.title: When is surgery needed?
content.description: Surgery is only needed if the cyst is large, painful, persistent, or possibly cancerous.

items.title: Laparoscopy
items.description: Keyhole surgery using small cuts. Often used for smaller, benign cysts.

items.title: Laparotomy
items.description: Open surgery through a larger cut in the abdomen. Used for larger or possibly cancerous cysts.

content.value: **Most cysts resolve on their own without surgery.**
Taking care of yourself can help manage symptoms and support your health.

items.text: Track your symptoms (pain, bloating, period changes)
Manage stress and rest if in discomfort
See your doctor early if anything feels unusual

content.value: If you're experiencing symptoms or have concerns about ovarian cysts, our team is here to help.
